quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 12 Quiz 7
quiz.subtitle: 12.7: Le Chatelier's Principle: Pressure and Volume Changes
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: If the volume of a reaction vessel containing an equilibrium mixture of gases is decreased, the system will shift in the direction that:
options: Reduces the total number of gas molecules
Increases the total number of gas molecules
Increases the temperature of the system
Decreases the value of the equilibrium constant $K$
questions.explanation: Decreasing volume increases pressure. The system counteracts this by shifting to the side with fewer moles of gas to alleviate the pressure.

questions.question: For the reaction $\text{N}_{2}\text{(g)} + 3\text{H}_{2}\text{(g)} \rightleftharpoons 2\text{NH}_{3}\text{(g)}$, what happens if the pressure is increased by decreasing the volume?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right (products)
The equilibrium shifts to the left (reactants)
No shift occurs because the temperature is constant
questions.explanation: The reactant side has $4$ moles of gas, while the product side has $2$ moles. Increasing pressure favors the side with fewer moles (the products).

questions.question: In which of the following reactions would a change in pressure have **no effect** on the equilibrium position?
questions.explanation: In this reaction, there are $2$ moles of gas on both the reactant and product sides ($\Delta n = 0$). Since the number of gas molecules is the same, pressure changes do not cause a shift.

questions.question: Increasing the volume of a container (which decreases pressure) will cause a shift toward the side with:
questions.explanation: A larger volume provides more 'room'. The system shifts toward the side that creates more gas particles to fill that space and restore pressure.

questions.question: If an **inert gas** (like Helium or Argon) is added to an equilibrium mixture at **constant volume**, what happens to the equilibrium position?
options: It shifts to the side with fewer moles of gas
It shifts to the side with more moles of gas
questions.explanation: While the total pressure increases, the partial pressures (and concentrations) of the reacting gases remain the same. Therefore, the ratio in the $Q$ expression does not change.

questions.question: Consider the reaction $\text{PCl}_{5}\text{(g)} \rightleftharpoons \text{PCl}_{3}\text{(g)} + \text{Cl}_{2}\text{(g)}$. If the volume of the container is doubled, the concentration of $\text{Cl}_{2}$ will:
options: Initially decrease, then increase slightly as the equilibrium shifts right
Initially decrease and stay at that new value
questions.explanation: Doubling the volume immediately halves all concentrations. Because the right side has more moles of gas ($2$ vs $1$), the system shifts right to compensate, slightly raising the $\text{Cl}_{2}$ concentration from its lowest point.

questions.question: Pressure changes primarily affect equilibrium systems involving which state of matter?
questions.explanation: Gases are highly compressible, meaning their concentrations change significantly with volume changes. Solids and liquids are nearly incompressible.

questions.question: In the reaction $\text{C(s)} + \text{H}_{2}\text{O(g)} \rightleftharpoons \text{CO(g)} + \text{H}_{2}\text{(g)}$, which side is favored by an increase in pressure?
options: Neither; they have an equal number of moles
The side with the solid carbon
questions.explanation: There is $1$ mole of gas on the left ($\text{H}_{2}\text{O}$) and $2$ moles of gas on the right ($\text{CO} + \text{H}_{2}$). Remember to ignore the solid! Higher pressure favors the side with fewer gas moles.

questions.question: Decreasing the volume of the reaction $2\text{NO}_{2}\text{(g)} \rightleftharpoons \text{N}_{2}\text{O}_{4}\text{(g)}$ will make the mixture:
questions.explanation: The product side has $1$ mole of gas while the reactant side has $2$. Decreasing volume (increasing pressure) shifts the balance toward the side with fewer molecules.

questions.question: What happens to the value of $K_{p}$ when the volume of a container is halved at constant temperature?
questions.explanation: Only temperature can change the value of the equilibrium constant. Physical changes like volume/pressure only shift the relative amounts of substances present.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've got a great handle on pressure and gas moles.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You correctly identified how volume changes affect gas equilibria.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: only count the moles of GAS, and ignore solids!
scoreMessages.0: Review the relationship between pressure, volume, and the number of gas moles in a reaction.
